The craftsmanship in catalyst synthesis becomes very fascinating when the catalytic activity of the material can be enhanced by tuning the synthesis conditions. The underlying fundamental strategy is presented here in tailoring the structural and chemical behavior of the tantalum phosphates (TaP) by using different structure directing agents (SDAs). We found that by employing appropriate template assisted pathway it is possible to tune the morphology and the nature of active sites of TaP. The synthesised catalysts were comprehensively characterised by N2-physisorption, FESEM, HRTEM, powder XRD, FTIR, UV–Vis, XPS, NH3 and CO2-TPD, Py-adsorbed IR, elemental analysis and 31P{1H} NMR techniques. The FESEM and HRTEM analysis revealed the transition of non-spherical to rod-shaped particles upon moving from ionic to non-ionic surfactants. The TPD and Py-IR studies revealed the variation in amount, strength and nature of the acidic-basic sites with the change in SDA. The resultant TaP catalysts were investigated for gas phase glycerol dehydration to acrolein and liquid phase glycerol carbonylation to glycerol carbonate. Among these catalysts, TaPC synthesized by using CTAB as SDA exhibited promising catalytic activity in both gas and liquid phase reactions. The active site elucidation in TaPC catalyst was done by adopting basic probe molecule 2,6-lutidine. The deactivation kinetic study was carried out for the gas phase glycerol dehydration reaction. The investigation on the spent catalyst showed it is stable under both gas-phase and liquid-phase reaction conditions. This study hence provides a pathway for analytical architecture and construction of highly efficient TaP catalysts for glycerol transformation reactions. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Soft template Tantalum phosphate Acrolein Glycerol carbonate Surface acidity-basicity 1 Introduction The inherent tendency of solids to reduce void spaces within their structures makes the synthesis of porous materials even with the aid of structure directing agent (SDA) or template very difficult. The scientists at Mobil oil corporation made this challenging task possible by first synthesizing the MCM (Mobil Composition of Matters)−41/48 via the surfactant mediated self-assembly method. [1] This surfactant aided templating approach introduces a new class of materials, the mesoporous materials. The Greek prefix ‘Meso’ which means in between has been adopted by IUPAC for defining porous materials with pore dimension between micropore and macropore (2–50 nm). [2] Due to their exceptionally high surface area and nanoscale porosity these mesoporous materials can be used as catalysts, catalyst supports, adsorbents, ion-exchanges and many other related applications. [3,4] Surfactants play the crucial role of designing the nanostructure and thus one can tune the catalytic activity by using suitable SDA in the synthesis. [5] Cationic surfactant molecules having long chain are employed as the SDA for the synthesis of MCM-41. [1] The mesoporous materials are retrieved by successive elimination of the surfactant by calcination or extraction. The surfactant templating pathway have been successfully employed in the synthesis of non-silica-based materials like metal oxides, metal sulphides, metal phosphates etc. Depending upon the nature of the organic fragments present in the molecular building blocks and their dimensionality play an important role in shaping the entire physico-chemical architecture of the resulting mesoporous material. [6] Owing to the strong interaction of the metal-phosphate sites and cross linking, these are chemically robust materials having enormous potential to be explored as efficient heterogeneous catalysts. The group VB phosphates are very much attractive because of their strong acidity and high-water resisting properties. Ample investigation has been carried out on niobium phosphate and vanadium phosphate catalysts. On the other hand, due to its high strength, high temperature resistance, acidity, ductile and bioinert nature tantalum incorporated materials have diverse applications in various sectors. [7] Materials like tantalum oxides, tantalum modified molecular sieves, tantalum oxophosphate have applications in capacitor insulator, fuel cell technology and as acid-base catalyst. [8–10] Works by Morales et al., Xing et al., Sarkar et al. and Zhang et al. have demonstrated the preparation of acidic tantalum phosphate and their application in different biomass conversion reactions. [11–15] Thus, mesoporous tantalum phosphate becomes a very interesting catalytic system to be applied in gas phase and liquid phase conversions. Fossil fuels being a nonrenewable energy source have a harsh effect on environmental sustainability and emit enormous quantities of greenhouse gasses on burning, which cause global warming and environmental pollution. Depletion of fossil fuels and sustainability of the environment are the reason that many researchers have seriously begun to work on renewable or biobased feedstocks for bulk production of chemicals and as an energy source. Due to environmental benefits and performance of engine, biodiesel is one of the attractive choices amongst several substitute fuels with the objective to cut down the worlds dependency on petroleum. [16,17] The production of biodiesel takes place via the transesterification of vegetable oils where about 100 kg of major by-product glycerol is obtained per 1000 kg of biodiesel produced. [18] Over the last few years the glycerol demand for cosmetic, pharmaceutical, food etc. application has not grown to the same extent as the requirement and production of biodiesel. [19] This fact has projected glycerol as an attractive and economical starting material for the synthesis of value-added chemicals by different methods including oxidation, dehydration, hydrogenolysis, carbonylation, transesterification, esterification, etherification, acetylation etc. [20] The success and benefit of biodiesel production is hugely dependent on the market value of the by-product glycerol. One of the prime glycerol dehydration products is acrolein, which is used for the manufacturing of various chemicals like 1,3-propane diol, methionine, pyridines, glutaraldehyde, fragrances, flavours etc. From the further oxidation of crude acrolein acrylic acid is produced, which is used for the preparation of polyacrylates. [21–23] Acrolein is mainly produced by the oxidation of propylene, however in near future its production from glycerol may become economically attractive. [24] The selective glycerol dehydration to acrolein has largely been studied both in liquid and gas-phase with various different types of catalysts. Performing the reaction in liquid phase with acids increases the level of corrosion which makes its commercial implementation very difficult due to high equipment price, cost of maintenance, difficulty in catalyst separation and waste management. [24] To date various types of catalysts have been tested in the gas phase dehydration of glycerol including heteropolyacids, zeolites, metal oxides, modified mesoporous materials etc. This reaction is particularly dependent on acidic and textural properties of the catalyst. Apart from acrolein, acetol is also another major product generated from glycerol dehydration. However, over strong acidic sites acrolein is predominant. [24] The formation of acrolein is favorable over medium to strong acid sites, however the strongest acid sites also might promote the formation of coke more, which may lead to a faster deactivation of the catalyst. For the production of acrolein production the use of raw glycerol without water removal can be advantageous. Therefore, a catalyst with high water tolerance and long-term acidity is preferred for this process. As per the mechanism the dehydration is initiated by the central hydroxyl of glycerol forms 3‑hydroxy propanal, followed by further dehydration to form acrolein. In parallel dehydration at terminal hydroxyl group leads to acetol formation. It was observed in reports that Bronsted acid sites are more flexible compared to the Lewis acidic sites and have ease of accessibity to the central hydroxyl of glycerol to ultimately form acrolein. Meanwhile terminal hydroxyl groups are more accessible by Lewis acid sites for the initiation of dehydration where formation of acetol is predominant. Hence sufficient emphasize is needed for incorporation of Bronsted acidic site to dominantly produce acrolein. On the other side glycerol carbonate or 4-hydroxymethyl-1,3 dioxolan is also a very significant chemical among various glycerol derivatives. It is widely used as an intermediate for fuel additive, polymers, protic solvent, lithium battery electrolyte, preparations for polycarbonates, surfactants, cosmetics, pharmaceuticals etc. [25–27] Glycerol carbonate can be synthesized by different pathways by reacting glycerol with carbondioxide, by using dimethyl carbonate or by reacting glycerol with urea. [28–30] Keeping the toxicity, waste management, tough reaction condition and low yield at bay, the carboxylation of glycerol with urea is one of the most prominent pathways to synthesize glycerol carbonate. One of the major utilities of this route is that the raw material urea is inexpensive and readily available. On the other side the reaction by-product ammonia can be re-employed to make the process more efficient. The glycerol carbonylation with urea has been performed with various catalysts like mixed oxides, heteropolyacids, hydrotalcite, zeolites etc. which resulted in high glycerol carbonate yields. Here it is worth noticeable that catalysts having merged acid-base sites exhibited enhanced catalytic activity towards the synthesis of glycerol carbonate. In our objective to modify the diversified properties of metal phosphate, we have tuned the properties of tantalum phosphate by using different SDAs during the synthesis to investigate its aftermath on the physical and chemical properties. The catalytic properties of the tailored tantalum phosphates were evaluated in the gas phase dehydration of glycerol to acrolein and liquid phase carbonylation of glycerol-to-glycerol carbonate (Scheme 1). Herein we ventured to synthesize mesoporous tantalum phosphate by employing different SDAs and studied their catalytic efficiency towards both gas phase and liquid phase reactions. The strategies employed during the synthesis of the materials showed influence on physico-chemical properties such as morphology, surface area and most importantly the strength and nature of acidic sites. The synthesized material exhibited promising catalytic activity and stability for both gas phase dehydration and liquid phase carbonylation of glycerol. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and reagent CTAB (NCetyl-N,N,N-Trimethyl Ammonium Bromide, Loba Chemie, India, 98%), SDS (Sodium dodecyl sulfate, Loba Chemie, India, 99%), Pluronic F-127 (Sigma-Aldrich, USA, 99%) Phosphoric acid (Alfa Aesar, USA, 85% aq. Solution), Tantalum Pentachloride (Alfa Aesar, USA, 99%), Ethanol (Changshu Yanyuan Chemical, 99.9%, China), Glycerol (Alfa Aesar, USA, 99%) and Urea (SD Fine Chemical, India, 99%) were purchased and all analytical grade materials were used for preparation without any further purification. 2.2 Preparation of the catalyst The catalysts were prepared by one pot evaporation induced self assembly sol gel method. [31,32] Here following surfactants with different ionic nature were considered for the study, CTAB (Cationic), SDS (Anionic) and F-127 (Non-ionic). Firstly, surfactant was dissolved in ethanol at room temperature. After that TaCl5 was taken in ethanol and added slowly and it was allowed to stir for 1 h followed by addition of 85% aq. solution of H3PO4 dropwise. The mixture was then allowed to stir at ambient temperature for 4 h and then for slow evaporation of the mixture; it was kept at 65 °C for 48 h. The obtained material was calcined at 400 °C for 4 h at 1 °C min−1 ramping in static air in a muffle furnace (Thermcraft, USA). The amount of the tantalum pentachloride and phosphoric acid and surfactant was taken in such a way to make their final molar gel ratio as Ta:P:CTAB=1:3:0.5, Ta:P:SDS=1:3:0.5, Ta:P:F127=1:3:0.5 denominated as TaPC, TaPA and TaPN. After the catalytic run the used TaPC sample is designated as TaPCRdeh for glycerol dehydration and TaPCRcar for glycerol carbonylation reaction. 2.3 Characterization of catalyst The N2 physisorption of the catalysts was done at liquid nitrogen temperature using Micrometrics Gas Sorption Analyzer (Model:3FLEX3500). The samples were subjected to degassing at a high vacuum at 300 °C for 3 h. After that the nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured the surface area was calculated by the Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) equation and the pore size distributions were calculated using Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. The field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM) and energy-dispersive x-ray spectroscopy (EDX) analysis was done by using Supra 55 from Carl (Zeiss, Germany), microscope with an oxford instrument X-max detector and an attachment of Gemini beam line. Lacey carbon was used as sample support and then gold coating was given by plasma prior to the measurement. The high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) analysis was done on Thermo Scirntific (Talos F200X G2) microscope with accelerating voltage of 200 kV. For TEM analysis, the samples were dispersed in ethanol and drop-casted on copper grid with carbon film.The X-Ray diffraction study was done with a Rigaku Smartlab high resolution X-Ray Diffractometer (HRXRD) with Cu Kα radiation source. The XRD analysis has been performed with Malvern Panalytical X'pert HighScore Plus software and Phases were identified by matching the experimental patterns to the JCPDS PDF database. The FT-IR analysis was done with the use of Perkin Elmer spectrophotometer (GX, USA). The spectra was taken in the range of 400–4000 cm−1 by the use of KBr pellets. UV-Visible experiment was done by using Shimadzu Varian Cary 500 series spectrophotometer (Japan). The elemental analysis (CHNS) was carried out using Elementar UNICUBE analysis system (Germany). The XPS spectra were collected using a source of Al K-Alpha Monochromate (1486.6 eV), 15 kV x 15 mA = 225 W, on an Axis Ultra Dld spectrometer. Survey spectra were recorded in the range of 1200 to 0 eV, with a pass energy of 160 eV, a step of 1 eV and a dwell time of 100 ms. The high-resolution spectra were recorded in the regions of O 1 s, C 1 s, Ta 4f and P 2p with a pass energy of 40 eV, and a step of 0.1 eV, the dwell time being. of 200 ms. Neutralization of charge effects on the sample surface is achieved with a low energy electron beam. The spectra are calibrated for binding energy using the C 1 s (CC, CH) photoemission peak at 284.8 eV. Ammonia and Carbon dioxide temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD) technique was used to measure the acidity and basicity of the samples respectively in a Micromeritics ChemiSorb 2750 model instrument (USA). Around 200 mg sample was degassed in a helium flow at 300 °C for 1 h and then it was cooled to ambient temperature before adsorption. A sample was given diluted NH3 or CO2 flow of 30 mL/min at ambient temperature for their adsorption. In order to remove the physisorbed NH3 a flow of helium was given at 100 °C for 1 h. TPD experiments were done in 50–800 °C temperature range under the flow of dry He. The O2-TPO analysis was performed on an AutoChem 2950 chemisorption analyzer (Micromeritics, USA) with a TCD detector. At first the catalysts were pretreated at 100 °C for 1 h in helium gas then the spectra were recorded by flowing of O2/He (5%) in the temperature range of 50–800 °C. The Py-IR of the catalysts were carried out at room temperature using a praying mantis accessory on Agilent Cary 660 FT-IR spectrometer (USA). Before pyridine adsorption the samples were dried for 1 h at 100 °C in a hot air oven. Around 50 mg of each sample was taken in a sample cup and then 0.1 ml of pyridine was added to it. After that in order to remove any physisorbed pyridine the sample cup was kept for 1 h at 120 °C in a hot air oven. After the sample cooled down the IR spectrum was taken using KBr background. For the high temperature Py-IR HARRICK temperature controller was used. For the chemisorption of 2,6-lutidine in the catalyst, the TaPC catalyst was kept in a desiccator to maintain moisture free condition. Then the sample was saturated with 2,6-lutidine and heated at 150 °C for 2 h to remove physisorbed molecule. Later, it was used in the corresponding reaction as 2,6-lutidine-treated-TaPC catalyst. 31P{1H} NMR spectra were recorded in a JEOL (ECX400, 400 MHz, Japan) spectrophotometer at room temperature equipped with a magic angle spin probe. 2.4 Catalytic test 2.4.1 Procedure for gas phase dehydration of glycerol to acrolein Gas phase catalytic reaction was performed in a down flow fixed bed tubular quartz reactor (9 mm i.d.) under atmospheric pressure. At first, quartz glass reactor was loaded with 0.25 g catalyst (60–80 mesh) and placed in reactor furnace. To obtain isothermal conditions the reactor was surrounded by glass wool. Then pre-treatment was done at a temperature 300 °C by nitrogen (purity 99.999%) at a flow rate of 30 mL/min maintained by a mass flow controller (Alicat, USA) for 1 h. A thermocouple was attached to monitor the temperature in the furnace. Then the reaction was initiated by the introduction of the reactant (20 wt% glycerol) through the syringe pump (B Braun) at a flow rate of 1 mL/h, vaporised at 200 °C temperature in a preheater. The reaction was performed at a temperature range (280–320 °C) by flowing nitrogen (15 mL/min). The reactor outlet is attached with ice coated collection chamber where pale yellow product was collected at different time interval. The collected product was analysed by gas chromatography (Agilent 7890B) equipped with an HPFFAP column (30 m length × 0.320 mm ID × 0.25 µm thickness) and flame ionization detector. The conversion and selectivity were calculated using the following equations. The quantification was done using calibration curve by injection of reference compounds. Here Zp represents carbon number in a particular product and ZGly represents carbon number in glycerol. c o n v e r s i o n o f g l y c e r o l = i n i t i a l m o l e s o f g l y c e r o l − r e m a i n i n g m o l e s o f g l y c e r o l i n i t i a l m o l e s o f g l y c e r o l x 100 % S e l e c t i v i t y o f p r o d u c t = m o l e s o f p r o d u c t f o r m e d m o l e s o f g l y c e r o l c o n v e r t e d x Zp ZGly x 100 % 2.4.2 Procedure for liquid phase carbonylation of glycerol to glycerol carbonate with urea The tantalum phosphate catalysts were dried at room temperature in vacuum and were used for catalytic tests without any further activation. The catalytic activity experiments of glycerol carbonylation were carried out in a double necked round bottom flask (50 mL) connected with a reflux condenser. In a typical catalytic test glycerol (2 g, 22 mmol), urea (1.306 g, 22 mmol) and catalyst (0.2 g, 60–80 mesh) were taken in the RB and subjected to magnet stirring through a cylindrical magnetic stirrer bar (size 20 mm × 8 mm) at 700 rpm at the required temperature which was maintained in a heated silicon oil bath. The stirrer speed of 700 rpm was maintained to ensure that the rate of the reaction is free from the influence of the external diffusion. [33] Nitrogen gas was bubbled through the second neck of the round bottom flask at a flow rate of 15mLmin−1 (flow maintained by Alicat mass flow controller) to remove the emerged NH3 gas formed in the course of the reaction. After the reaction was completed then methanol was added, followed by the separation of the catalyst by filtration. For the catalyst recycle experiment, after completion of the reaction the catalyst was washed with methanol followed by drying at 100 °C and finally further used in the next reaction cycle. The liquid sample was analysed by gas chromatography (Agilent 7890B) equipped with an HPFFAP column (30 m length × 0.320 mm ID × 0.25 µm thickness) and flame ionization detector by using 1,4 dioxan as an internal standard. The conversion and selectivity were calculated using the following equations. c o n v e r s i o n o f g l y c e r o l = i n i t i a l m o l e s o f g l y c e r o l − r e m a i n i n g m o l e s o f g l y c e r o l i n i t i a l m o l e s o f g l y c e r o l x 100 % S e l e c t i v i t y o f g l y c e r o l c a r b o n a t e = m o l e s o f g l y c e r o l c a r b o n a t e f o r m e d m o l e s o f g l y c e r o l c o n v e r t e d x 100 % 3 Result and discussions 3.1 Physicochemical characterization The properties accessed from the N2 physisorption analysis of the template assisted tantalum phosphate catalysts are given in Table 1 . Fig. 1 represents the N2 physisorption isotherms for the TaPC, TaPA and TaPN materials at 77 K. In the relative pressure (P/Po) range 0.5–0.99 all the catalysts exhibited Type-IV isotherm with H3 hysteresis loop suggesting the mesoporous nature of the materials. [34,35] The loop of this type is given by loose aggregates of plate like particles forming slit like pores. The BJH pore size distributions of TaPC and TaPA showed uniform pore size distribution whereas the TaPN showed quite broad and multipore size distribution. The surface area of the catalysts decreases in the following order TaPC>TaPN>TaPA. Therefore, it can be inferred that the textural properties are strongly persuaded by the type of SDA employed in the synthesis. The surface morphology of the tantalum phosphate catalysts was depicted by the FESEM analysis shown in Fig. 2 . The catalysts showed inhomogeneous nonspherical nanoflakes with mixed shapes, circular and elongated depending upon the type of SDA employed in the synthesis. Among them for the TaPC catalyst, it is seen that the surface morphology of the catalyst showing nonspherical circular nanoflakes. [36,37] The particle size of the TaPC catalyst ranges from 0.20 to 0.55 µm with a mean particle size of 0.35 µm. In case of the TaPA catalyst, its particle size decreases ranging from 0.06 to 0.27 µm with a mean particle size of 0.14 µm. The TaPA catalyst also possesses nonspherical nanostructures but with a rather smaller particles which are fused to create an aggregated morphology. In the FESEM results of the TaPN catalyst, the particles are ranging from 0.28 to 1.14 µm with an average particle size of 0.58 µm having a nanorod morphology. The variation in the architecture of TaPs by engaging different SDAs could be associated with the micelle formation in different orientations leading to diverse self-assembly resulting in the growth of TaPs with different morphologies. To acquire further insights into the morphology of the template assisted TaPs, bright field HRTEM and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) images were taken shown in Fig. 3 . For the TaPC catalyst the images confirm the presence of nanoflake like morphology which justifies the presence of Type H3 hysteresis loop as discussed in the N2-physisorption analysis. [38] In case of the TaPA catalyst the particles seem to be in a fused and aggregated nature. The TEM images of the TaPN catalyst clearly reveals the formation of rod like particles which is also evident from the FESEM images. Moreover, the SAED patterns of the catalyst show bright and sharp diffraction indicating the well crystalline nature of the materials. The obtained d-spacing from the SAED pattern and its comparison with the reported XRD d-spacings are shown later in Table 2 at the x-ray diffraction analysis. In case of ionic surfactants strong electrostatic force comes into play. For both the cationic and anionic surfactant upon successive addition of metal and phosphate precursor, formation of surfactant-metal-phosphate cluster takes place driven by electrostatic interactions. On the other hand, formation of the ionic-surfactant complexes means decrease in the effective collision between the metal phosphate forming ions which explains their inhibitory action in the overall particle growth process. [39] In case of the non-ionic surfactant the possibility of the electrostatic interaction may be eliminated. According to Lee and coworkers these non-ionic surfactants could form the surfactant-metal-phosphate cluster through hydrogen bond interactions. [40] These intermolecular interactions could enable nucleation and particle growth to proceed upon mixing the reagent solutions according to the template micelles leading to rod like shapes. Furthermore, with increasing alkyl chain length the CMC effectively decreases. So, in case of ionic surfactants the average size of the CTAB micelles will be bigger compared to that of SDS micelles, thus nanoparticles with smaller size were obtained in case of SDS compared to CTAB. For non-ionic surfactants its lower solubility in comparison to the ionic ones makes the CMC decrease and the space between micelles also increases thus inducing a steric hindrance that further contributes to increase the size of the particles produced which again facilitates elongated rod like shape. The stronger effect of sequestering exerted by the ionic surfactants might hinder the immediate release of the surfactant species upon subjected to thermal treatment and likely to disturb the atomic arrangement which is in turn responsible for the less ordered structure formation in presence of ionic surfactants. The arguments are in good agreement with our SEM and TEM observations. The Fig. 4 (a) represents the wide angle XRD profile of the tantalum phosphate catalysts. All the three catalysts have phases of tantalum phosphate and tantalum oxide. In the XRD pattern of TaPC catalyst the reflections at 2θ=20.07° and 21.83° can be indexed to planes (201) and (011) respectively for the phase TaPO5 (Monoclinic, JCPDS: 00–025–0923). The reflections at 2θ=27.32° and 34.49° are assigned to the planes (110) and (101) for the respective following phases Ta2O5 (Orthorhombic, JCPDS: 00–025–0922) and TaO2 (Tetragonal, JCPDS: 00–037–0117). In case of the TaPA catalyst the peaks at 2θ=20.43° and 21.30° can be indexed to planes (201) and (011) respectively for the TaPO5 (Monoclinic, JCPDS: 00–025–0923) phase; whereas peaks at 22.65° and 34.59° is attributed to (001) and (101) planes for the following phases, Ta2O5 (Orthorhombic, JCPDS: 00–025–0922) and TaO2 (Tetragonal, JCPDS: 00–037–0117). On the other hand, for TaPN catalyst the reflections at 20.40° and 21.26° 2θ can be indexed to planes (201) and (011) respectively for the phase TaPO5 (Monoclinic, JCPDS: 00–025–0923); while the reflections 22.65° and 34.46° is assigned to (001) & (101) planes for the phases Ta2O5 (Orthorhombic, JCPDS: 00–025–0922) and TaO2 (Tetragonal, JCPDS: 00–037–0117). The XRD analysis affirms the possible presence of tantalum dominantly in Ta+5 state. These results suggest that the crystallization of the catalysts could be influenced by the type of SDA employed during the synthesis under similar reaction conditions due to the change in chemical and physical properties associated with the SDA molecules. Table 2 shows the obtained d-spacing values from the SAED and the reported d-spacing values from XRD. As can be seen, the attained values (SAED and XRD) agreed well with each other. The FTIR spectra of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 (b). For each catalyst the broad band at 3410 cm−1 and 1631 cm−1 is attributed to the stretching and bending vibration of hydroxyl groups (-OH) of adsorbed water molecules respectively. [13] The IR band at 1274 cm−1 is assigned for the P-OH stretching frequency of the uncoordinated phosphate groups. [11] The band at around 1080 cm−1 may be due to the P-O asymmetric stretching vibration. [14] The band at 956 cm−1 is assigned for the Ta-O-P bond vibration. [15] The band at 604 cm−1 and 502 cm−1 corresponds to the Ta-O-Ta and Ta-O bending mode respectively. [8,11] Fig. 4 (c) portrays the UV–Vis spectra of the three catalysts. The FTIR analysis establishes the structural integrity of the materials. The broad band of adsorption in the range of 220–230 nm can be accredited to ligand {O2−(2p)} to metal {Ta+5(5d)} charge transfer transitions. [41] This indicates that the tantalum atoms are present in penta and tetra coordinated environment which is consistent with the results obtained from the XRD analysis. [31] According to the study by Moniri et al. they have concluded that a shift towards longer wavelength (red shift) in the peak position is observed for the materials having longer particles. [42] In this study we can clearly observe that there is a peak position shift towards higher wavelength in case of the TaPN catalyst which possess larger particles as evident from the FESEM and HRTEM analysis. The surface chemical composition of the three tantalum phosphate catalysts was evaluated by x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis. The XPS spectra and atomic concentration of the elements have been shown in Fig. 5 , Figure S1, Figure S2 and Table S1. XPS spectrum of tantalum in the 4f core level region has been depicted in Fig. 5 (b) where two peaks corresponding to Ta4f7/2 (peak 5) and Ta4f5/2 (peak 6) are can be observed at 28.0 and 29.9 eV respectively. [11,43] The binding energy separation of 1.9 eV along with an area ratio of 1.41 eV affirms that Ta is in Ta(5+) oxidised state. The presence of tantalum in Ta(1+) and Ta(2+) state can be seen in trace amounts (Peak 1 to Peak 4, Fig. 5 & Table S1). [44] The binding energy value of 532.4 eV for TaPC corresponding to O1s peak indicates that oxygen is present in O2− species. [45] The P2p spectrum reflects two peaks at 134.3 eV (peak 1) and 135.2 (peak 2) which indicates the presence of phosphorus in P(5+) state. [32] The binding energy values and XPS spectrum of the TaPA (Figure S1) & TaPN (Figure S2) catalysts indicates the existence of elements in the same oxidation state with that of the TaPC catalyst. So, the XPS analysis suggest that there is no significant change in the oxidation state of the present elements upon employing different type of SDA during the synthesis. The amount of acidic sites and basic sites in the TaP catalysts was determined by the NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD technique as shown in Table 3 and the NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD desorption profiles are presented in Fig. 6 . The tantalum phosphates prepared using different SDAs exhibited diversity in total no. of acidic and basic sites. The TaPC catalyst synthesized with the cationic surfactant showed the highest acidity. The total acidity in the TaP catalysts decreases in the order TaPC>TaPN>TaPA. This might be due to the fact of comparatively higher external surface area in TaPC followed by TaPN and TaPA. The acidic strengths of the catalysts are quantified and given in Table 3 and Fig. 6 (c). The total acidity of the catalyst is attributed to the positively charged metal centres (Lewis) and P-OH centres (Bronsted) combined. The strength of acidic sites is distinguished in the following temperature range as weak (50–250 °C), moderate (250–500 °C) and strong (500–800 °C) based on desorption temperature. So, for the TaPC catalyst it is clearly evident that the moderate acidic sites are majorly contributing in its total acidity but for TaPA and TaPN catalyst the strong acidic sites have more contribution in the gross total acidity. The larger particle size in TaPN catalyst might be a contributing factor behind the presence of higher amount of strong acidity. [46] The basic strength of the catalysts is quantified and given in Table 3 and Fig. 6 (d). The origin of the basic sites in metal phosphates are mainly correlated with the surface oxygens bonded with the positively charged metal centres. The total basicity of the TaP catalysts follows the same trend of its acidity; TaPC>TaPN>TaPA. As seen from the CO2-desorption diagram strong basic sites are the main contributing factor behind the total basicity of all the catalysts. The nature of acidic sites in the TaP catalysts were investigated by the pyridine-FTIR analysis. The interaction of pyridine with Lewis acid sites (denoted as L) gives rise to bending vibrations at 1450 cm−1 and 1610 cm−1. The bands at around 1550 cm−1 and 1640 cm−1 corresponds to the pyridine which is bound to the Bronsted acidic sites (denoted as B). The band at 1490 cm-1 is assigned to the overlapping of both Bronsted and Lewis acidic sites. [47,48] The IR band intensity provides a perception about the particular acidic site concentration in a material. From Fig. 7 (a) it is clearly recognized that the intensity of the IR adsorption bands acquired by the TaPC catalyst is the most intense whereas it is lowest with TaPA catalyst which is in conformity with the results obtained from NH3-TPD analysis. The Bronsted acidity in the catalysts originate from the surface -OH groups (P-OH) whereas the Lewis acidity is attributed to the presence of the metal center. The probe molecule pyridine is too big to be adsorbed in micropores but can only be adsorbed on the external surfaces. This explains the higher intensity peaks shown by TaPC and lowest by TaPA. On an interesting note, the B/L ratio follows the order of TaPN (7.7)>TaPC (4.09)> TaPA (3.76). Figure S3 depicts the pyridine adsorbed FTIR of the TaP catalysts taken at 300 °C which clearly reveals the stable nature of acidic sites. These results affirm the fact that the acidic sites in tantalum phosphate can be tuned by utilizing different types of SDAs as a modulator. The solid state 31P{1H} NMR technique was carried out to classify the distribution and nature of the local phosphorus environments which arises due to the incorporation of different SDAs at the time of synthesis in Fig. 7 (b). The chemical shifts at around 1.3 ppm and −4 ppm range are attributed to a mixed tetrahedral phosphorus environment with connectivity three [HPO4 2−] and four [PO4 3−] respectively. [41,49] The resonance peaks in the range −5 to −11 ppm signifies the presence of (H2PO4)− species, to −19 ppm for (HPO4)2- and finally from −20 ppm to −33 ppm for (PO4)3− species. As progressive deprotonation takes place in the phosphate species, acidity decreases. From the relative intensity of the 31P{1H}NMR spectra of the three catalysts the presence of surface acidic sites (P-OH) is following the order of TaPC>TaPN>TaPA. It can be easily inferred that the high amount of Bronsted acidic sites in the TaPC catalyst is because of the presence of higher surface P-OH groups which is also evident from Py-FTIR. Also, it can be further concluded that the relative amount of phosphate species and the enrichment of P-OH species varies with the different SDAs employed in synthesis. Scheme 2 3.2 Catalytic activity for glycerol dehydration The surfactant mediated TaP catalysts were employed for gas phase dehydration of glycerol at 300 °C temperature and atmospheric pressure under flowing of 20 wt.% of aqueous glycerol through the catalyst bed. The glycerol conversion and product distributions are elucidated in Fig. 8 , where 8 h time courses give hydroxyacetone and acetaldehyde as major by-products along with formation of acrolein as a main dehydrated product. The glycerol dehydration reaction undergoes via two side by side pathways based on the nature of the acidic sites. Brønsted acid sites follow the protonation route of secondary hydroxyl group, leads to formation of acrolein through less stable 3-hydroxypropanal intermediate and primary hydroxyl group protonation pathway is accompanied by Lewis acidic sites causes production of hydroxyacetone. [50,51] These two pathways are aided in the formation of several by products such as acetaldehyde, acetic acid, acetone. [24] Witsuthammakul and Sooknoi et al. suggested earlier that the heavier product can be formed from reactive acrolein through several secondary reactions, such as condensation and oligomerization and denoted as others. [52] The conversion of synthesized catalysts was varied from one another as their differences in total acid amount varied. The best glycerol conversion 89% was achieved for TaPC catalyst within 2 h of introduction and approached 82% after 8 h, while at the same time the conversion for TaPA and TaPN catalysts reached approximately 62% and 73%. Since the external surface area of TaPC is larger than other two, which enacts glycerol molecule to access the internal acidic sites in better way. In the manner of speaking, the glycerol conversion follows the order of TaPC> TaPN> TaPA which is in agreement with accessible internal acidic sites. In the context of product distributions, the acrolein was appeared as a major product and its selectivity is high at initial introduction period and gradually going down with time owing to the increase in selectivity of hydroxyacetone and other products. It is noteworthy to mention that the molar ratio of acrolein to hydroxyacetone in the products is associated with the BAS/LAS ratio of a catalyst. [53] A corelation of BAS/LAS with acrolein/hydroxyacetone is established and described in Fig. 9 . Where, an increase in acrolein/ hydroxyacetone ratio with increasing BAS/LAS (TaPAB/ L = 3.76, TaPCB/ L = 4.09, TaPNB/ L = 7.7) ratio justified that the Brønsted acidic sites are preferable over Lewis acidic sites for selective conversion of glycerol to acrolein. Surprisingly, the acrolein selectivity was found to be more or less equal for all catalysts at any time despite of having different BAS/LAS ratio. To resolve this issue, we have pre-treated our catalyst (TaPC) with a basic molecule such as 2,6-lutidine, prior to the glycerol dehydration reaction. As we know, the 2,6-lutidine selectively combines with Brønsted acidic sites while two methyl groups of this 2,6-lutidine molecule curb the interaction with Lewis acidic sites. A 32% conversion of glycerol (TOS 4 h) was observed when the lutidine treated sample was employed for the dehydration reaction, indicating the contribution of Lewis acidic sites in catalytic performances. It is worth saying that the Brønsted acidic sites are not solely accountable for obtaining the acrolein especially in the case of TaPC and TaPA catalysts where Lewis acid amount is high. Finally, it can be inferred from above experiment that the Lewis acidic sites also contributed along with Brønsted acidic sites for production of acrolein. This result complied with earlier reports by Wang et al. and Alhanash et al. [54,55] The dehydration reaction is temperature sensitive. To find out the optimum temperature, the glycerol dehydration was investigated at three different temperatures shown in Fig. 8 (d). Initially, the glycerol conversion and selectivity of acrolein increased with rising up the temperature from 280 to 300 °C. However, a drop of selectivity of acrolein was observed with further increasing temperature from 300 to 320 °C. Thus, higher reaction temperature has an adverse effect on acrolein selectivity as the Lews acidic sites comes into play at higher temperature which favours the hydroxyactone formation. It is observed earlier that the glycerol dehydration to hydroxyactone over Lewis acidic sites has highest activation barrier rather than acrolein over Brønsted acidic sites which makes the acrolein formation process thermodynamically unfavorable at higher temperature. [51,56] Nevertheless, at all reaction temperatures, the acrolein is the major product and by products including hydroxyactone, acetaldehyde and along with some undesired product and unreacted reactant which eventually polymerizes to produce coke at reaction temperature and blocks the small pores. From the elemental analysis (Table S2) the increased percentage of carbon clearly indicates that there is deposition of coke in the catalysts after reaction. The coke deposition follows the order of TaPCRdeh> TaPARdeh> TaPNRdeh. Owing to the higher acidity in the TaPC catalyst higher deposition of coke is evident. After the regeneration of the TaPCRdeh catalyst in air we can clearly notice the reduction in amount of carbon deposit which is due to the loss of carbon as CO2 in presence of air. In order to further explore this scenario, we have performed the TPO analysis given in Figure S4. The peaks observed are attributed to the removal of carbon in the form of CO2. [57] From the O2-TPO profile it is clearly evident that there is a substantial amount of coke in the TaPC catalyst after reaction. The higher uptake in the higher temperature range (400–700 °C) in case of the TaPCRdeh catalyst is due to the burning of hard coke. [24] Based on our observations and literature reports [51,52,54,58], a tentative path way is proposed and depicted in Scheme 3 . At first glycerol molecules over TaP catalyst gets protonated either at the primary or at the secondary hydroxy group. Protonation leads to the removal of primary hydroxyl group as a water molecule preferably over Lewis acidic sites, producing hydroxyacetone or removal of secondary hydroxyl group in the form of water to produce a less stable intermediate 3-hydroxypropanal, mainly catalysed by Brønsted acidic sites. Later, 3-hydroxypropanal yields acrolein over Brønsted or Lewis acidic sites. Generally, Bronsted and Lewis acidic sites control the acrolein selectivity above 250 °C whereas effect of Lewis acidic sites is predominant above 300 °C at higher temperature. On the other hand, acetaldehyde is formed through cracking of dehydration product such as acrolein, hydroxyactone over acidic sites. 3.2.1 Deactivation kinetics The stability of a catalyst is a foremost factor to determine its fate as a productive catalyst in glycerol dehydration reaction. Though, our catalysts have a less deactivation tendency ( Fig. 8 ), still a desirable form of deactivating kinetics was adopted for as synthesized catalysts under constant flow rate. As reported by Levenspiel, the deactivation behavior of each catalyst in glycerol dehydration is described with respect to glycerol conversion at different time intervals [59]. It is well known that glycerol dehydration follows first order reaction kinetics regarding glycerol (n = 1). A catalyst experiences independent deactivation and undergoes only structural modification or sintering when it is exposed under extreme condition for long time. The decay is independent of concentration in the gas stream but dependent on the spent duration at a high temperature (300 °C) ambiance. The rate of disappearance ( − r G ) of the reactant (glycerol) over a heterogeneous catalyst is represented in (Eq. i) and the rate at which the activity decreases with time may be written in (Eq. ii) [55,58] (i) ( − r G ) = k C G n a (ii) − d a d t = k d a d Where k and k d represent the rate constant and deactivation rate constant, C G and a are the glycerol concentration and catalyst activity function respectively. While n and d are the reaction order and deactivation order respectively. The catalyst activity function "a" starts from one and fall to zero with time ( t ). Hence, the reacted reactant for continuous system is represented in Eq. Where k and k d describe in L. gcat −1. min−1 and min−1 respectively. [59] The deactivation kinetic models for each catalyst were tested under identical reaction conditions and displayed in Fig. 10 . The observed rate constants ( Table 4 ) decreased with decreasing trend of acid amount. Interestingly, it is obtained that the reaction and deactivation rate constant both are larger for TaPC compared to other synthesized catalysts. Gu et al. and Clacens et al. suggested [61,62] stronger acidic sites could be a reason for accelerating catalyst deactivation through formation of heavier products. A distinctive result is obtained in our case, where the TaPN showed least deactivation rate instead of having highest stronger acidic sites ( Fig. 6 a) among other two. But an exciting relation was observed, when we compared the micropore surface area with deactivation rate. In the case of TaPC and TaPA catalyst, the deactivation order is high and almost equal to each other since they consist of larger volume of micropores. Which resists the diffusion of adsorbed glycerol or product molecule and facilitates the secondary reaction. So, the active sites are located inside the micropores become inaccessible to such an extent that the reaction is governed by internal diffusion. On the other hand, the negligible amount of micropore volume makes the TaPN catalyst effective toward the coke tolerance as the surface is mainly enriched by mesopores. The larger pore size increases the diffusion rate and curtails the residence time of intermediate and product by providing comparatively bigger space around active sites which impedes the intramolecular interaction among intermediates and prevents coke formation as well. A comparison of catalytic performances of TaP catalyst with respect to previously reported catalysts is made and tabulated in Table S3. Although the comparison draws a conclusion from the catalytic data found in literatures are not appropriate as different condition was adopted for different catalyst to obtain best performance. Some catalysts in the table (Entry 1,2,4,6,8–10) might have shown complete conversion and good selectivity but their stability lies only for short time courses which keeps them away to become a good catalyst. It is seen that the FeP-H catalyst (Entry 7) was capable of achieving 100% conversion and 92% selectivity at a low temperature (260 °C) but it is not that much worthy as an effective catalyst in terms of catalyst loading. However, a small amount of Fe/AlPO4–450 catalyst (Entry 5) is sufficient for complete conversion but insufficient for obtaining good selectivity. Additionally, the hydrated Ta2O5 catalyst (Entry 11) managed to achieve high selectivity for prolonged time but unable to reach satisfied conversion. In this context, our catalyst is superior in terms of stability as well as good catalytic performances under moderate operation conditions. 3.3 Catalytic activity for glycerol carbonylation The catalytic activity of the different template assisted tantalum phosphate catalysts were also evaluated for the liquid phase solvent free carbonylation of glycerol to glycerol carbonate. Among the different TaP catalysts, the TaPC catalyst showed the highest conversion of 88% with 98% selectivity towards glycerol carbonate. As can be seen from Fig. 11 (a), the TaPA catalyst resulted 61% conversion with 93% selectivity and TaPN catalyst resulted 76% conversion with 95% selectivity for glycerol carbonate. The superior performance of the TaPC catalyst to that of other TaP catalysts is mainly attributed to the presence of higher acidic and basic sites along with a comparatively higher surface area which results in a better distribution of active sites in the catalysis [33]. This provides effortless accessibity to the reactants and facilitates easy diffusion of molecules. Thus, the TaPC catalyst was selected as the best catalyst for further studies. The impact of reaction temperature was studied with the TaPC catalyst and the results are given in Fig. 11 (b). At 110 °C temperature only 26% conversion of glycerol could be observed with 92% glycerol carbonate selectivity. Raising the temperature from 110 °C to 140 °C a profound increase in conversion was observed. The glycerol conversion increased from 26% to 88% and the selectivity increased from 92% to 98% towards glycerol carbonate. On further increment in temperature no significant change was observed in the conversion and selectivity. Therefore, 140 °C was chosen as the optimum temperature and considered for further studies. The reaction time optimization study is shown in Fig. 12 (a). With increasing time, the conversion of glycerol showed an increasing trend. However, the glycerol carbonate selectivity altered marginally with time. At 4 h the glycerol conversion reached 88% with 98% selectivity towards glycerol carbonate. Prolonging the reaction time further though there was a slight increase in conversion but a minute decline in selectivity was also evident. The reusability of the catalyst was explored under optimised reaction conditions for four consecutive cycles (Fresh, R-1, R-2, R-3, R-4) shown in Fig. 12 (b). The spent catalyst was filtered and washed with methanol in order to remove any reactant from the catalyst surface after every cycle, followed by drying in oven prior to use in the next cycle. From fresh reaction to consecutive recycles slight decrease in conversion and selectivity is observed which can be attributed to glycerol adsorption on the active site of the catalyst and/or formation of phosphate esters with glycerol. [63] These results suggest that the TaPC catalyst is stable and reusable without much substantial loss of activity and proves to be a potential catalyst to yield glycerol carbonate. 3.3.1 Comparison of glycerol carbonylation The performance of the TaPC catalyst was compared with other reported catalysts given in Table S4. Various catalytic systems are reported for the glycerol carbonylation reaction with urea. SW21, Zn1TPA, Sm0.66TPA, Co3O4/ZnO, La2O3, Zn/MCM-41(im) catalysts showed good selectivity towards glycerol carbonate but the conversion of glycerol was low while the reverse was noticed for Au/Fe2O3, 2.5% Au/Nb2O5, Sn-beta and ZnAlO catalysts. The Ta0.4TPA and Zr-P catalysts showed 71% and 80% glycerol conversion respectively with maintaining >99% selectivity for glycerol carbonate attributable to the presence of merged acidic and basic sites in them. However, in the above mentioned catalysts like Zn-Y, ZnSn(OH)6 and Zn2Sn-Co-Pre-600, higher reaction temperature (>150 °C) is used along with very high amount of catalyst (>300 mg). The catalytic results of the TaPC catalyst shows that it has promising catalytic activity towards the synthesis of glycerol carbonate. 3.3.2 Mechanism of glycerol carbonylation In order to selectively synthesize cyclic carbonates involving di-ols and urea it is evident that catalysts possessing both acidic and basic properties are more favourable. [64] Investigations by Shanbag et al. found that catalysts with optimum acid-base properties can exhibit incredible results for glycerol carbonylation reaction. [30,65] Marrakatti et al. also proposed that Lewis acidic sites and conjugate basic sites are the reason behind the appreciable catalytic activity towards glycerol carbonate synthesis. [47] A bunch of investigations by Lingaiah et al. reported that the presence of Lewis acid and its conjugate base is favourable for the selective synthesis of glycerol carbonate. [26,66,67] Keeping all the above conclusions into account a plausible reaction mechanism can be proposed for glycerol carbonate synthesis with glycerol and urea over tantalum phosphate catalyst as shown in Scheme 4 . In the first step, the basic sites present in TaP catalyst activate the hydroxyl group of glycerol, whereas the acidic sites activate the carbonyl group of urea. In the second step, the lone pair of electrons present on the hydroxyl group of glycerol attacks the carbonyl carbon and forms an intermediate with the elimination of ammonia. In the last step, this intermediate undergoes cyclization by the attack of adjacent hydroxyl group on the tertiary carbocation leading to the formation of glycerol carbonate followed by the elimination of another molecule of ammonia. In this context the Ta+5 center (Lewis) and P-OH group (Bronsted) acts combinedly as acidic site and the framework oxygens provide the basic sites. So, the presence of dual site makes it a good bi-functional catalyst to exhibit admirable catalytic efficiency towards the synthesis of glycerol carbonate. 3.4 Study of the spent catalysts The stability of the spent catalyst (TaPCRdeh and TaPCRcar) for both the gas phase and liquid phase reaction was investigated by nitrogen sorption, XRD and Py-IR techniques. The nitrogen sorption analysis for the spent catalysts (Figure S4, Table S2) reveals a decline in surface area for both the cases. In case of TaPCRdeh catalyst the decline is more comparted to the TaPCRcar catalyst. But in case of pore diameter some increment can be noticed for the TaPCRdeh catalyst compared to the fresh one. According to Atia et al. and Hultberg et al. this might be due to the phenomena of pore condensation by glycerol, where accumulation and clogging of pores by glycerol condensation takes place and smaller diameter pores become less available in the spent catalyst. [68,69] The EDX analysis (Table S2) of the fresh and spent catalysts indicates no leaching of tantalum and phosphorus species. The XRD analysis (Figure S5) of the spent catalysts shows quite similar pattern retaining all the characteristic peaks of the parent catalyst. The py-IR spectra (Figure S6) of the spent catalysts indicates the presence of considerable amount of Bronsted and Lewis acidity after reaction in comparison to the fresh catalyst. The amount of acidity of the TaPCRdeh seems to be higher than that of the TaPCRcar, but interestingly the B/L ratio remains almost similar (B/L TaPCRdeh=4.21, B/L TaPCRcar=4.13). Thus, the physico-chemical properties of the spent catalysts indicate that the catalyst is stable under both gas and liquid phase reaction conditions. 4 Conclusion In this work we have performed a comprehensive modulation on the soft template mediated synthesis of mesoporous tantalum phosphate materials and their application in glycerol transformation reactions. Engaging different SDAs considerably influenced the structural and chemical properties of tantalum phosphates. Comprehensive characterization was carried out for all the tantalum phosphate catalysts. From the N2 physisorption we have concluded about the porosity of the three different materials. The microscope analyses (FESEM, HRTEM) have shown the growth of the particles upon moving from ionic to non-ionic SDAs. The variation in the architecture of the TaPs by engaging different SDAs could be associated with the micelle formation in different orientations leading to diverse self-assembly resulting in the growth of TaPs with different morphologies. From the structural analyses (XRD, FTIR, UV, XPS) we have evidenced the presence of Ta+5 in the majority. The acidity-basicity studies (NH3-TPD, CO2-TPD, Py-IR, 31P{1H} NMR) clearly reveals the change in amount, strength and nature of the acidic basic sites with the variation of the SDA. The comparatively higher surface area and acidity is the main reason behind the enhanced catalytic activity of the TaPC catalyst. Responsible active sites in TaP catalyst for glycerol dehydration reaction are enlightened by probing with 2,6-lutidine which confirms the importance of not only Bronsted acidic sites but also Lewis acidic sites. Interestingly, the flexibility in controlling and tuning of morphology and acidic-basic sites with various strength and nature directed by SDA is noteworthy. The deactivation kinetics study has been carried out for the glycerol dehydration reaction which compliments the analysis of the coke deposition that we have carried out. For achieving high yield in the glycerol carbonylation reaction the bi-functional nature of the catalyst is very much essential. The study of the spent catalyst showed it is stable under both gas-phase and liquid phase reaction conditions. Our experimental results revealed that these mesoporous catalysts are stable under both gas-phase and liquid phase reaction conditions. This could be accredited to the unique association of structural and chemical properties of the catalysts and explains its potential catalytic behavior. In a nutshell, the synthesis and catalysis results showed new opportunities to tune the physico-chemical properties of tantalum phosphate materials for a vast range of catalytic transformations for the synthesis of value-added fuels and fine chemicals. coredata.dc:description: The craftsmanship in catalyst synthesis becomes very fascinating when the catalytic activity of the material can be enhanced by tuning the synthesis conditions. The underlying fundamental strategy is presented here in tailoring the structural and chemical behavior of the tantalum phosphates (TaP) by using different structure directing agents (SDAs). We found that by employing appropriate template assisted pathway it is possible to tune the morphology and the nature of active sites of TaP. The synthesised catalysts were comprehensively characterised by N2-physisorption, FESEM, HRTEM, powder XRD, FTIR, UV–Vis, XPS, NH3 and CO2-TPD, Py-adsorbed IR, elemental analysis and 31P{1H} NMR techniques. The FESEM and HRTEM analysis revealed the transition of non-spherical to rod-shaped particles upon moving from ionic to non-ionic surfactants. The TPD and Py-IR studies revealed the variation in amount, strength and nature of the acidic-basic sites with the change in SDA. The resultant TaP catalysts were investigated for gas phase glycerol dehydration to acrolein and liquid phase glycerol carbonylation to glycerol carbonate. Among these catalysts, TaPC synthesized by using CTAB as SDA exhibited promising catalytic activity in both gas and liquid phase reactions. The active site elucidation in TaPC catalyst was done by adopting basic probe molecule 2,6-lutidine. The deactivation kinetic study was carried out for the gas phase glycerol dehydration reaction. The investigation on the spent catalyst showed it is stable under both gas-phase and liquid-phase reaction conditions. This study hence provides a pathway for analytical architecture and construction of highly efficient TaP catalysts for glycerol transformation reactions.
coredata.dc:title: Soft-templating routes for the synthesis of mesoporous tantalum phosphates and their catalytic activity in glycerol dehydration and carbonylation reactions
